entry.et: Middle English partie part, party, from Anglo-French, from partir to divide part

def.dt: :a person or group taking one side of a question, dispute, or contest
:a group of persons organized for the purpose of directing the policies of a government
:a person or group participating in an action or affair a mountain-climbing party a party to the transaction
:a particular individual :person an old party approaching 80
:a detail of soldiers
:a social gathering
:the entertainment provided for it
:to attend or give parties
:revel 1
:a person known for frequent often wild partying
:the policy or practice of a political party
:a single telephone circuit connecting two or more subscribers with the exchange called also party wire
:the principles or policies of an individual or organization
:the explanation or interpretation usually put forth the party line that her mother was a saint Leslie Bennetts
:a person who refuses to join in the fun of a party
:one who refuses to go along with everyone else
:a wall which divides two adjoining properties and in which each of the owners shares the rights
:a party for invited guests that follows a main party or event
:an outdoor public party put on by the residents of a city block or neighborhood
:an informal or semiformal party or gathering at which cocktails are served
:a party for women only
